topic_name: Block storage: Local disk, iSCSI, SAN (random access, block based).. local or remote disk!!

questions.question: What is the fundamental characteristic that distinguishes block storage from file storage?
options: Block storage can only be accessed locally
Block storage presents data as raw blocks that the operating system formats with a filesystem
Block storage is always faster than file storage
Block storage can only store structured data
questions.explanation: Block storage presents raw, unformatted blocks of data that the operating system then formats with a filesystem. This is different from file storage which presents a pre-formatted filesystem interface.

questions.question: A database administrator needs to provision storage for a high-performance database that requires low latency random access patterns. The storage must appear as a local drive to the database server but needs to be shared across multiple servers for failover purposes. Which solution would be most appropriate?
options: Network File System (NFS)
Storage Area Network (SAN) with Fibre Channel
Object storage like Amazon S3
Direct-attached SATA drives
questions.explanation: A SAN with Fibre Channel provides block-level access with low latency, appears as local storage to the OS, and can be shared across multiple servers for clustering and failover scenarios.

questions.question: When comparing local disk storage to iSCSI for a virtual machine environment, what is the primary trade-off an administrator must consider?
options: Local disk is always more secure than iSCSI
iSCSI provides better performance but requires more complex configuration
Local disk offers better performance but iSCSI enables features like live migration and centralized management
iSCSI can only be used with Linux virtual machines
questions.explanation: Local disk typically offers better performance due to no network overhead, but iSCSI enables advanced virtualization features like live VM migration and centralized storage management, despite some performance trade-offs.

questions.question: Why might an organization choose iSCSI over Fibre Channel SAN for their block storage implementation?
options: iSCSI provides better performance than Fibre Channel
iSCSI can leverage existing Ethernet infrastructure and is more cost-effective
iSCSI supports larger storage volumes than Fibre Channel
iSCSI provides better data encryption capabilities
questions.explanation: iSCSI runs over standard Ethernet networks, allowing organizations to leverage existing network infrastructure and expertise, making it more cost-effective than Fibre Channel which requires specialized hardware and skills.

questions.question: In a block storage system, an application writes data to what appears to be block 1000 on a logical volume, but the storage system actually writes it to block 5000 on the physical disk. This scenario best demonstrates which concept?
options: File system fragmentation
Storage virtualization and logical block addressing
Data compression
RAID parity calculation
questions.explanation: This demonstrates storage virtualization where logical block addresses (LBA) presented to the application are mapped to different physical block addresses on the storage device, providing flexibility in storage management.
